Section 10 Modeling Rather than an introduction to statistics, I want to walk through how to read R model output. We will make an interaction model with the customer type and day of week. R models generally follow the formula style: y ~ b0 + b1x1 + .... They’re create from function just like everything else. The simplest model is the linear model, lm(). Let’s first wrangling the data into the structure we need for modeling. trips_per_day <- nice_ride_2018 %>% group_by(usertype, start_day) %>% summarise(trips = n()) mod <- lm(formula = trips ~ usertype * as.character(start_day), data = trips_per_day) mod ## ## Call: ## lm(formula = trips ~ usertype * as.character(start_day), data = trips_per_day) ## ## Coefficients: ## (Intercept) ## 42221 ## usertypeSubscriber ## -23947 ## as.character(start_day)Mon ## -7595 ## as.character(start_day)Sat ## 11880 ## as.character(start_day)Sun ## 7543 ## as.character(start_day)Thu ## -4499 ## as.character(start_day)Tue ## -9633 ## as.character(start_day)Wed ## -5534 ## usertypeSubscriber:as.character(start_day)Mon ## 7253 ## usertypeSubscriber:as.character(start_day)Sat ## -17477 ## usertypeSubscriber:as.character(start_day)Sun ## -12583 ## usertypeSubscriber:as.character(start_day)Thu ## 6160 ## usertypeSubscriber:as.character(start_day)Tue ## 10428 ## usertypeSubscriber:as.character(start_day)Wed ## 7432
